Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 8. The Sage Asita's Predictions
Manual - Tibetan (བོད་ཡིག།): Vol. Ka (1) and vol. Kha (2) pp. 12-13.

Sun of Faith - English: In the company of his disciple Naradatta, Asita the sage set to see the Bodhisattva.
Manual - Tibetan (བོད་ཡིག།): དེ་ནས་གྲོང་ཁྱེར་སེར་སྐྱའི་བཀོད་པ་གཞན་ཞིག་གི་ཁང་བཟང་དུ། ཡབ་ཀྱི་སྐུ་པང་དུ་བཞུགས་པ་ལ། མདུན་དུ་དྲང་སྲོང་ཁ་དོག་མི་ཤ་ཁ་ནག་པོ། རལ་པ་སེར་སྐྱ་འཛིངས་ཤིང་ཁ་སྤུ་ནག་པོ་ཅན།  ཚངས་སྐུད་དང་དབྱུག་གུ་སྤྱི་བླུགས་ཡོད་པ། རྒན་པའི་ཆ་བྱད་ཅན་ཞིག་གི་བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་ལ་ལྟ་ཞིང་། ལག་པ་གཡས་ཅུང་ཟད་སྒྲེང་བ་དང་། ཕྱོགས་གཞན་ཞིག་ཏུ་དྲང་སྲོང་དེ་རྒྱལ་པོའི་དྲུང་དུ་མཆིལ་མ་འདོན་པའི་ཚུལ་བྱ་བ་དང་། ཕོ་བྲང་དེའི་ཕྱི་རོལ་ན་དྲང་སྲོང་དེ་ཚུར་ཡོང་དུས་ཀྱུས་མ་ཡོང་བ་དང་། ཕར་འགྲོ་དུས་ནི་སྒོའི་ཕྱི་ནས་དར་རས་སོགས་སྐྱང་བའི་སྟེང་། དེ་དང་ཉེ་བའི་བྲག་ཕུག་གཅིག་ཏུ་དེ་ཉིད་བསམ་གཏན་ལ་གནས་པའི་ཚུལ་དང་། དེའི་མདུན་དུ་དྲང་སྲོང་གཞོན་ནུ་གཅིག་འབྲི། དེ་དག་ནི་ལྷུམས་སུ་ཞུགས་པ་དང་བལྟམས་པའི་སྐོར་རོ།།   ༼ཁ༽དེ་ནས་མ་མ་བརྒྱས་སྐོར་བའི་བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་བྱིས་པའི་ཚུལ་གྱི་གསེར་གྱི་གཞོང་པ་ཤིན་ཏུ་ཆེ་བ་འབྲས་ཀྱིས་བཀང་བ། ཕྱོགས་གཅིག་ནས་གླང་པོ་ཆེ་མང་པོ་ལ་བཏགས་ལ། བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་ཁྱེའུའི་ཕྱག་མཛུབ་གཅིག་གིས། གཞོང་པ་ནས་འཐེན་པས། གླང་པོ་ཆེ་རྣམས་ཀྱང་འདྲེད་སྟབས་སུ་ཚུར་དྲུད་པ། འབྲས་ཆེན་ནས་གསོལ་བའི་རྣམ་པ་ཡང་འབྲི་སྟེ། ཕྱག་གཡོན་པས་སྣོད་ནས་འཐེན་ཚུལ་དང། གཡས་པས་གསོལ་བའི་རྣམ་པ་བྱས་ན་ལེགས།
Manual - English: In Kapilavastu, in a mansion, the Buddha sits the king's lap. A sage looks at the Buddha and slightly held up his right hand. He is an old man with dark skin, unkempt grayish yellow hair, and black moustache. He carries a brahma thread, cane, and sacred water vase and pills (spyi blugs). When the sage is on his way to the palace, he is treated as an ordinary visitor. But when he leaves, he walks on the silk spread on the path spread outside the palace gate. In a cave, the sage abides in samadhi with a young man before him. [Vol. Kha (2)]: The Buddha is surrounded by a hundred nannies. There is a large golden tray filled with rice.  One side of the tray is tied to a flock of elephants with ropes. When the Buddha pulls the tray with one finger, he also pulls away all the elephants. The Buddha drinks rice gruel. It is better if the Buddha pulls the bowl with left hand and eats right-handed.

Sun of Faith - English: They traveled much of the way by magical means.
Manual - English: In a cave, the sage abides in samadhi with a young man before him.

Sun of Faith - English: As they drew near to Kapilavastu, they were overwhelmed by the Bodsattiva's splendor. They were no longer able to travel magically, so they proceeded on foot.
When they reached the city gates of Kapilavastu, they called out to the sentinels, who went to inform the king.
Manual - English: When the sage is on his way to the palace, he is treated as an ordinary visitor.

Sun of Faith - English: The king respectfully invited them inside.
Manual - English: In Kapilavastu, in a mansion, the Buddha sits the king's lap. A sage looks at the Buddha and slightly held up his right hand. He is an old man with dark skin, unkempt grayish yellow hair, and black moustache. He carries a brahma thread, cane, and sacred water vase and pills (spyi blugs).

Sun of Faith - English: He invited them to rest on fine seat.
The king made them feel at ease with his honest way of speaking, and then asked, "Great sage, why have you come?"
Asita said, "I have come to see your son."
"Right now the child is sleeping," said the king. "Please stay until he awakes."
"I would watch the sleeping god," said Asita.
When the sage went to look he saw the bodhisattva staring at shapes with unblinking eyes.

Asita said,
"The well-bred horse
Sleeps but a quarter night.
For those with great purpose,
Sleep lingers not upon the eyes."
Asita understood that he was a great being.
Scene working notes: This seems to simply be Taranātha's summary of Asita's previous praise.

Sun of Faith - English: Then the head nurse handed the Bodhisattva to the sage, who examined him well.
Asita asked the king, "What predictions did the  sooth-sayers make for this divine youth.
The king explained the earlier predicition: "There are two paths this great being can go by."

The sage Naraddata said,
"Oh Lord, the pundits are mistaken.
In strife-filled times no monarch comes.
This source of Dharma and great virtue
Will conquer sleep, and awaken.
If the thirty-two signs are somewhat unclear, he would become a wheel-turning monarch. The are totally clear, so he will become a Buddha."
Examining with a sage's clairvoyance, Asita saw that he would die before the Buddha turned the wheel of dharma. He realized he would not partake in the feast of Dharma and tears fell from his eyes.
Scene working notes: In the Vinayavastu passage, Asita also predicts that the child will leave his home at age 29 and perform austerities for six years.

Sun of Faith - English: The king saw Asita and, fearing he had found something troubling on the youth's body, anxiously questioned the sage. Fearful that the saint had detected some harmful indication that might bear on his son's health, the king plied him with questions.

Asita said, "A violent hailstorm of diamonds could fall and this youth would not be harmed.
Lord of Men, I have seen my own decline,
So I'll find no peace at all.
I've met this supreme source of Dharma,
Though I will die without achieving my aim."
Scene working notes: Here the Lhasa Kangyur has <rgyud> instead of <rgud>

Sun of Faith - English: Then Asita the Sage started to leave. All of the streets were cleaned and decorated, and the King, together with his ministers escorted him to the outer gates of the city.
The Sage Asita then returned to his home and his miraculous powers returned.
Sometime after that the Bodhisattva was sitting in his nurse's lap eating rice and meat from a golden bowl.
Manual - English: The Buddha is surrounded by a hundred nannies. There is a large golden tray filled with rice.

Sun of Faith - English: "If he eats too much he will have indigestion," thought the nurse. She tried to stop him, but she could not. She started to take the bowl away, but she could not.
The King, Queen Maya, the ministers and many others were also unable.
The golden bowl was attached to a rope, and the rope was attached to five hundred elephants, one after the other. The elephants moved away from him, yet he drew it in with a one hand.
Manual - English:
One side of the tray is tied to a herd of elephants with ropes. When the Buddha pulls the tray with one finger, he also pulls away all the elephants. 
The Buddha drinks rice gruel. It is better if the Buddha pulls the bowl with left hand and eats right-handed.

Sun of Faith - English: "If he is able to draw in five hundred elephants with his left hand," they thought, "with both hands he could draw a thousand!" So they called him Strength of a Thousand Elephants.
